Bro, it feels a lot like other suspense movies I’ve seen. That was my first reaction watching Don’t Move. The truth is, the film even tries to innovate in its theme—and it does, partly. It brings tense scenes, moments where people with anxiety (like me) will feel rage, will scream. But that’s not enough. The movie slips badly in the script. The cabin scene goes by in a flash. Well, of course—it’s not very long, and the film’s pacing gives off a lazy writing vibe, as if each scene just “happens,” with no strong purpose. There’s a lack of clear motivation from the killer, no backstory for the victim or the serial killer, and no explanation of how he got there: to the park, the cliff. Sure, with everything I pointed out, the film would need to be a bit longer. That weakens the whole experience.
It’s not just about suspense or jump scares. It’s about building tension with substance—and Don’t Move doesn’t do that. Nowadays, a lot of what we see isn’t about quality, but quantity. And that seems to be the case here: a movie with few actors, few locations, and probably a limited budget. Did something come out of it? Yes. Good? I don’t think so. Watchable? Like all of them, yes.
